description: Unknown. Slang attested in African-American and rural American culture. Frequently used to imply lying, verbal deception or trickery. Has a possible historical antecedent in gyve (“shackle”). Alternatively, of African origin, compare Wolof jev, jeu (“to talk about someone absent, especially in a disparaging manner”).

entries.meaning: (uncountable) A dance style popular in the 1940–50s.
(uncountable) Swing, a style of jazz music.
(uncountable) A slang associated with jazz musicians; hepcat patois or hipster jargon.
(US, colloquial) Synonym of bullshit: patent nonsense, transparently deceptive talk.
examples: Don’t give me that jive. I know where you were last night.

entries.meaning: (US, colloquial, often derogatory) African-American Vernacular English.

verbs.description: jive (third-person singular simple present jives, present participle jiving, simple past and past participle jived)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, US, colloquial) To deceive; to be deceptive.
examples: Don’t try to jive me! I know where you were last night!

entries.meaning: (intransitive, colloquial) To dance, originally to jive or swing music; later, to jazz, rock and roll, rhythm and blues, disco, etc.

verbs.description: jive (third-person singular simple present jives, present participle jiving, simple past and past participle jived)

entries.meaning: (US) To jibe, in the sense of to accord, to agree
